evidence_span: Static rest potentials were measured at pH 5.5. similar to high purity reactor water at 250°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: At 25°C. the rest potentials for both zirconium and Zircaloys are below the equilibrium potential for the standard hydrogen electrode, SHE. at pH 5.5 and for pH2 = 1 bar.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: The rest potentials of the intermetallics are more noble than the SHE.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: At 250°C the range of potentials is narrower, yet the intermetallics are still more noble than the Zircaloy metal matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: The effect of coupling the zirconium alloy matrix to the intermetallic alloy at 25°C was demonstrated experimentally

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: As the relative area of intermetallic increases, the potential becomes more noble. Conversely, increasing the zirconium substrate area results in more active potentials.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Rp values from potentiodynamic tests were reported in Table 5. Indeed, the Zircaloy system is under anodic control. Relative Rp values are 143, 0.5, 6.8, and 2.1 MΩ/cm2 for Zr X bar, Zr2Fe, Zr(Fe,Cr)2 and Zr2(Fe,Ni).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: Weight gain data performed in steam help explain the role intermetallics play in the development on the oxide film. The higher relative weight gain of the intermetallics suggest that, when the intermetallic particles are incorporated into the growing oxide layer and are electrically isolated from the metal substrate, they will oxidize and or break up.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk5
evidence_span: However, it can be expected, when intermetallic particles serve as cathodic sites. that they are protected at the expense of the surrounding Zircaloy matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: Many nodule precursors were observed after exposure to $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ steam on materials expected to have both good and poor nodule resistance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The high density of intermetallic particles along the alpha-grain boundaries, typical of material quenched from the alpha $^ +$ beta zone, lowers the susceptibility of nodular corrosion by blocking or redirecting surface oxide cracks.
specimen_state: material quenched from the alpha+beta zone

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The finely dispersed intermetallic structure characteristic of Zircaloy, which has been beta-quenched late in processing, lowers nodule formation by increasing the precursor site density, thus distributing the stress fields more uniformly.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The larger size and randomly distributed intermetallic structure typical of material receiving final anneal(s) in the alpha zone is the least efficient in stopping nodule growth.
specimen_state: material receiving final anneal(s) in the alpha zone

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The large, randomly dispersed intermetallic structure of alpha-processed material generally results in low uniform corrosion rates by limiting the amount of cathodic surface area (intermetallics), while at the same time maximizing the electrical path length between anodic and cathodic areas.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: Conversely, material that has been beta-quenched late in processing and has a finely distributed intermetallic structure offers a greater number of cathodic sites while minimizing the path length between anodic and cathodic sites. This structure enhances the cathodic reduction of hydrogen ions and thus allows higher oxidation rates.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: Autoclave exposures for intermetallic compounds demonstrate that although they are more noble than the metal substrate, they typically have much higher oxidation rates than Zircaloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: Generally, if the stress gradients are low. because of either slower oxidation rates or more uniform surface oxidation (i.e., a less passive condition), better alloy performance can be expected.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: In more oxidizing environments, as in BWRs, the oxidation is localized in the form of nodular corrosion.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: This type of planar oxidation behavior is typically observed in more reducing PWR environments.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk6
evidence_span: The last type, more active behavior, can be observed under thick oxide film conditions or where LiOH enhancement occurs

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: oxide development photographs taken after exposure to 500‰ steam

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: Randomly distributed large intermetallic particles, shown in Fig. 14. Case 1, are typical of beta-quenching at slab thicknesses between 130 to 180 mm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: beta-quenching at slab thicknesses between 130 to 180 mm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: This microstructure encourages radial crack growth and thus rapid development of nodules

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: Alpha + beta annealing near final size causes the intermetallic particles to migrate to the grain boundaries

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
evidence_span: The resulting network of intermetallic particles form a barrier to crack propagation and thus slow the development of nodules

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_033_chunk7
